[[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] | relations = | laterwork = }} Captain '''John Steel Ralston''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|MC|DFC|sep=yes}} (27 April 1887 – 25 July 1918) was a Scottish World War I war hero and [[flying ace]]. After winning a Military Cross in 1916 for lifesaving gallantry while serving in the infantry, he was credited with 12 official aerial victories as a fighter pilot before he was [[killed in action]].{{cite web |url=http://www.theaerodrome.com/aces/scotland/ralston1.php |title=John Steel Ralston |work=The Aerodrome |year=2015 |accessdate=7 November 2015}} ==Biography== Ralston was born in [[Bothwell]], [[Lanarkshire]], Scotland, the youngest of five children born to Thomas Binnie Ralston, an iron merchant, and his wife Mary Chalmers (née Steel),{{cite web |url= http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/binniefamily/wc02/wc02_445.htm |title=Ralston - Steel |first=Pippa |last=Binnie |work=Binnie Family Tree (& beyond) |year=2009 |accessdate=7 November 2015}} and was educated at [[The Glasgow Academy]].{{cite book |url= https://archive.org/stream/glasgowacademyro1918glas#page/16/mode/2up |title=The Glasgow Academy Roll of Honour, 1914-1918 |location=Glasgow |year=1918 |accessdate=7 November 2015}} During the First World War, Ralston originally served with the 8th Battalion, [[Scottish Rifles]], being commissioned as a second lieutenant on 25 August 1915.{{London Gazette |issue=29288 |startpage=8966 |date=7 September 1915 |supp=yes |nolink=yes}} In November 1916, he won the Military Cross for rescuing a wounded comrade under fire. Ralston was seconded to the [[Royal Flying Corps]], and was appointed a flying officer on 12 June 1917.{{London Gazette |issue=30213 |startpage=7878 |date=31 July 1917 |supp=yes |nolink=yes}} He was promoted to lieutenant on 1 September.{{London Gazette |issue=30318 |startpage=10164 |date=28 September 1917 |supp=yes |nolink=yes}} Once assigned to No. 84 Squadron as a [[Royal Aircraft Factory SE.5]]a pilot, he began to succeed in aerial warfare. On 21 October 1917, he and [[Kenneth Leask]] drove down a German reconnaissance aircraft out of control. Ten days later, Ralston drove down an [[Albatros D.V]] out of control for his second win. He would not score again until 6 December, when he teamed with [[Robert Grosvenor (aviator)|Robert Grosvenor]] to drive down another German reconnaissance aircraft. On 23 December, he ended his year with his fourth "out of control" victory, driving down another reconnaissance aircraft. On 13 January 1918, Ralston became an ace when he destroyed a German two-seater reconnaissance aircraft over [[Crèvecœur-en-Auge|Crevecoeur]]. On 26 January, Ralston was appointed a [[flight commander]] with the accompanying rank of temporary captain.{{London Gazette |date=8 February 1918 |supp=yes |issue=30515 |startpage=1806 |nolink=yes}} On 16 February, he drove down an Albatros D.V. There was a lapse then, as he did not score again until 18 June 1918, when he drove down a [[Fokker D.VII]]. Nine days later, he put down a [[Pfalz D.III]] near [[Villers-Bretonneux]]. Then in July, he scored his final four wins, destroying three balloons, and assisting [[Norman Mawle]] in the destruction of a Fokker D.VII. Ralston would be awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross posthumously for his exploits, as he died on the day of his last victory, [[balloon buster|balloon busting]] south of [[Warvillers]] on 25 July 1918. ==Honours and awards== ;Military Cross :2nd Lt. John Steel Ralston, Scottish Rifles ::"For conspicuous gallantry in action. He carried a wounded man 100 yards across the open under heavy fire. He has displayed great courage and coolness throughout the operations.{{London Gazette |date=25 November 1916 |supp=yes |issue=29837 |startpage=11543 |nolink=yes}} ;Distinguished Flying Cross :Lieut. (T./Capt.) John Steel Ralston, M.C. (Scottish Rifles, T.F.). ::"An intrepid patrol leader who in recent operations has accounted for three enemy machines and three kite balloons. Recently while on patrol he advanced to attack a kite balloon; on his approach the balloon party began to haul it down, but forcing home his attack, he shot the balloon down in flames. In the engagement this officer was seriously wounded. Suffering great pain, he flew back to our lines and tried to land, but fainted and crashed.{{London Gazette |date=21 September 1918 |supp=yes |issue=30913 |startpage=11254 |nolink=yes}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ralston, John Steel}} [[Category:1887 births]] [[Category:1918 deaths]] [[Category:People from Bothwell]] [[Category:People educated at the Glasgow Academy]] [[Category:Cameronians officers]] [[Category:Royal Flying Corps officers]] [[Category:Royal Air Force personnel of World War I]] [[Category:British World War I flying aces]] [[Category:Recipients of the Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)]] [[Category:Recipients of the Military Cross]] [[Category:British military personnel killed in World War I]]
